awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Hybrid Blockchain to enable safe and transparent distribution of perishable goods
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to provide open and secure management of transactions between multiple parties in a supply chain. The lack of transparent information throughout the supply chain has eroded the trust and value of many perishable products and the brands they represent. The proposed project addresses the current issue of tracking and traceability of food products in a trusted manner. Through the development of a hybrid blockchain that is sensor aware, all the parties involved in the distribution of the goods will ensure that the food quality is maintained by entering transactions into a secure blockchain. The result is two-fold: consumers will be assured that they are getting the right goods and suppliers can trust that their products are being delivered with quality. While initially focused on the $2 billion food transaction market, the commercial potential will expand to a broader range of products that require secure traceability including consumer goods, home delivery and medical products.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop the core technology for the hybrid blockchain and test the functionality in a live commercial setting. The technology represents the first-in-class solution that leverages blockchain and DAGs (directed acyclic graphs) with integrated sensor and hybrid datasets to address the perishable nature of food products. The blockchain model will assume that a transaction is an event of data transfer and that there can be many disjointed events even on a small-scale supply chain network. For traceability, novel algorithms will be designed, making it feasible to connect disjointed events using geometry and a pseudo-Boolean function on top of a system that assigns a unique code. This implementation uses multivariate time series and node features for the meaningful aggregation and disaggregation of datasets, such as data collected by sensors and participating members. Putting such multivariate time series on the graph where participants are nodes with their pairwise relations as edges, the technology will address the novel optimization problem for efficient real-time monitoring and assist in providing further assurance of transaction integrity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OrganicSmart has successfully completed our Phase 1 research project, concentrating on the development of a robust platform for reliably tracking physical products through blockchain-enabled digitalization. The overarching objective of the SBIR project was to implement the initial proof of concept, with a specific focus on perishable goods. We have achieved a significant milestone by creating core technology that enables the activation of a physical and digital pair, facilitating the tracking of environmental events on a secure distributed ledger. 

The functional end-to-end system encompasses mobile applications, backend infrastructure, and IoT sensors enable physical products to be activated using customized NFC/RFID tags and allows activation and interaction via an iPhone. Passive IoT sensors strategically positioned in warehouses and shipping trucks offer real-time environmental monitoring during product transit. All activated products have associated digital NFTs that are minted by the product supplier via a customized mobile application. The NFT provides real-time linking between the physical and digital product, enabling end-users to benefit from trusted traceability. All transactions are recorded on a blockchain with a modified consensus mechanism, providing a verified history of the product from creation through current use. The platform has demonstrated applicability to a broad range of products, including produce and high-end assets such as cars.

The project is expected to have significant impacts across social and economic fronts. From a social perspective, the ability to have trusted tracking of products can improve product safety and deliver a more robust user experience. From an economic perspective, the solution can prevent fraud, improve supply chain efficiency, provide a deeper understanding of imports, and enable a decentralized market for secondary sales.

The primary use case of the proof of concept was centered around fine wines and spirits, chosen for their perishable nature and the strategic considerations that facilitated a streamlined and straightforward commercialization strategy. Throughout the SBIR timeline, our commercial assumptions underwent rigorous validation, achieved through in-depth interviews with key customers such as wineries and distillers, as well as collaboration with ecosystem partners within the supply chain.

The proof of concept is a fully functional prototype, showcasing the following capabilities:

  • Blockchain Transaction Confirmation Utilizing a Partially Ordered Set
  • Smartphone Pairing for Blockchain Transaction Validation
  • IoT-Based Sensor Network for Blockchain-Based Tracking
  • OS-Code System for Phygital Interactions Using NFC/NFT Pairing
  • NFT Asset Management System, named "Top Shelf"

During the Phase I project, we also conducted related research on emerging technologies in the food industry, Non-fungible Tokens (NFTs) and their marketplaces, Phygital, and the Web 3.0 supply chain network. Below are the titles and abstracts of the papers:

Disruptive Technologies and Their Impact on the Food Industry:

  • Abstract: Quality food is vital for healthy living, yet the market's lack of traceability and transparency poses challenges such as mislabeling, fraud, and information manipulation. This study addresses these issues by integrating disruptive technologies into the food supply chain. We propose a hybrid network, combining blockchain with a conventional database to enhance traceability. To ensure efficiency and security, an Internet-of-Things application using mobile device sensors is implemented, alongside computer vision for extracting information from paper-based invoices. Examples related to the food supply chain and restaurant operations are provided. Additionally, we explore the impact on food marketing and consumers' perspectives, shedding light on their influence on dining decisions.

The Art NFTs and Their Marketplaces:

  • Abstract: Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), powered by blockchain technology, are unique crypto assets providing a digital identifier for ownership. This paper explores the transformative impact of art NFTs on artists' sales strategies, revolutionizing the art trade market by eliminating intermediaries. NFTs distinguish originals from copies, facilitating trade by ensuring proof of ownership and file authenticity. We address the growing importance of NFT utility within the ecosystem, considering owners' benefits and profitability. Utilizing recent data from major art NFT marketplaces, we present concise summaries and interpretations of current market trends, offering insights into the future of the art market.

Web 3.0 D2C: A Paradigm Shift for Supply Chains:

  • Abstract: Emerging technologies, including blockchain and IoT, are reshaping business models by enhancing traceability, transparency, and communication systems. The evolution of blockchain architecture within Web 3.0 and smart contracts introduces a more flexible iteration, termed "Phygital," tailored for the business landscape. This paradigm shift fosters a versatile ecosystem, emphasizing the integration of blockchain and the phygital realm. This article provides a concise overview of the technical elements in a potential blockchain-based business model, highlighting its supplementary managerial advantages. Unlike previous studies that predominantly use a game theoretical approach, our research focuses on leveraging stochastic modeling techniques to uncover potential advantages, addressing inherent uncertainties and model complexity.

These papers are currently in the finalizing process and can be shared upon request. 

Our commitment to innovation and research positions OrganicSmart at the forefront of transformative advancements in the intersection of physical and digital realms.
